'''''Infundibulicybe gibba''''' (also known as '''''Clitocybe gibba''''') is a species of [[Lamella (mycology)|gilled]] mushroom which is common in European woods.  In English it is sometimes known as the  '''common funnel'''.<ref name=firstNature/>

==Naming==
This species was originally described by the mycologist [[Christiaan Hendrik Persoon]] in 1801 as ''Agaricus gibbus'', at a time when [[Lamella (mycology)|gilled]] mushrooms were generally all assigned to genus ''Agaricus''.<ref name=SF1/>  Then in 1871 in his guide to mycology ("Der Führer in die Pilzkunde"),  [[Paul Kummer]] allocated the species to the genus ''[[Clitocybe]]'', which previously (according to the system of [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fries]]) had only been a [[Tribe (biology)|tribe]] within genus ''Agaricus''.<ref name=Kummer/>

In 2003 Harri Harmaja created the new genus ''[[Infundibulicybe]]'' for some of the larger members of the former ''Clitocybe'' and he included ''Infundibulicybe gibba'' as the type species.<ref name=Eyssartier/><ref name=FN/><ref name=SF1/><ref name="Harmaja 2003"/>  A couple of authorities still keep it in genus ''Clitocybe'', however.<ref name=GBIF/><ref name=Mycobank/>

The older name '''''Clitocybe infundibuliformis''''' is often identified as a synonym of ''I. gibba'',<ref name=Bon/><ref name=Courtecuisse/><ref name=FN/> but according to [[Species Fungorum]] that use was incorrect and the original ''C. infundibuliformis'' was a different mushroom.<ref name=SF1/>

The epithet ''gibba'' comes from the Latin adjective "gibbus", meaning "humped" or "[[wikt:gibbous|gibbous]]".<ref name=Lewis1/>  The name ''infundibuliformis'' derives from the Latin "infundibulum", a funnel, with the suffix "-formis" - so it means "funnel-shaped".<ref name=Lewis2/>

==Description==
This section uses the given references throughout.<ref name=Bon/><ref name=Courtecuisse/><ref name=Eyssartier/><ref name=FN/>

*The matt slightly felted cap grows from about 3 cm to 8 cm, and is beige to ochraceous, also sometimes with a pink tinge.  It soon becomes funnel-shaped but often has a small bulge (an "[[Umbo (mycology)|umbo]]") in the centre.
*There is no ring or other veil remnant.  The stem is white or whitish and up to about 6 cm long and 1 cm in diameter. 
*The white gills are crowded and very [[decurrent]] (running down the stem).
*It has a faint "cyanic" smell, like new-mown hay, and the taste is mild.  However there is also a central European variety "''adstringens''" which has an unpleasant taste.<ref name=Courtecuisse/>
*The tear-shaped spores are around 5.5-8 µm by 4-5 µm.

==Distribution, habitat, ecology and human impact==
This gregarious [[saprobic]] mushroom grows on soil in deciduous or (less commonly) coniferous woods and may be found from summer to autumn.  It sometimes forms [[fairy rings]].

It is very common throughout Europe, and occurs in North America and Japan.<ref name=GBIF/><ref name=Courtecuisse/>

It is edible when young, but said to be of mediocre quality.  It can be fried or used in risottos or soups etc.  The stems are tough and may be discarded.<ref name=ElRoyo/><ref name=Bon/><ref name=firstNature/>

An [[extract]] of I. gibba exhibits inhibitory activity on [[thrombin]].<ref name="Doljak 2001"/>
